17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the numbers of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, etc.

Breakfast: pancakes, fried fish, meat, gravy, coffee.

Supper: potatoes, vegetables, meat, pudding, or rice.

Winter of 1911. Mrs. Van Dyke, Mrs. J. Van Dyke (my brother), Mr. Van Dyke

18. How did you serve your first Christmas dinner? In Eastern Canada?

19. Have you ever worked to almost starvation level living on one or two local products? If so, give details. No.
16. HOPPING AND CIVILIZING

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the date and list the approximate months, e.g., winter.

Breakfast: pancakes, bacon, butter, meal, pudding or rice.

Supper: bread, butter, meal, fried potatoes, fruit.

Winter of 1911: Mr. J. Van Dyke, Mrs. J. Van Dyke, children (my brothers). My mother was ill.

18. Tell us how you served your first Christmas dinner in Canada.

19. Were you ever subject to short starvation locally? If so, give details.
20. Mention any outstanding difficulties in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and supplies? (Give reasons, etc.)

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and supplies. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of purchasing, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other difficulties. Use back of pages if needed.

After we were settled on the homestead, once or twice a year a trip was made to Willmar, mostly a week's journey by horseback. We bought a little supply of groceries, etc. Then bought in Willmar while a few more stores were closed in the country. If in the early days our store was out of coal oil we burned candles. (I believe they knew that there were always some on hand for emergencies!)
21. When did you begin to rely on purchasing foods and supplies? (Give dates if possible.)

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and supplies. Tools in other ways, inside pioneer days in Eastern Canada.

23. It was not unusual above, quality, methods of transportation, etc., etc.

After we were settled on the homestead, we had with a team of oxen. These trips lasted mostly a week going in and coming back.

We bought a few more stores there closed in the country. If in the early days our store was out of coal oil we burned candles (of course) things closer that there were always some on hand for emergencies!
As it was mostly the men who went to the stores in the earlier days, I do not remember exactly all the prices and charges. I have done my best to inform you of what I did remember.

As the oldest member of our Homemakers Club, I hope that these informations will be of any use to you.

Yours sincerely,

Mrs. Jack van Dijke.
